content:
青春七月一日七三取善、肉桂阿例部份 Jos Proj. 39-471 IP
R-1112
The audit report concerning Excess Equipment Project No. 99-471 appears to be basically same as its draft which had been sent to CUSA for clearance but was not cleared by CUSA on account of its being not consistent with the facts and returned per CUSA letter C2-62-1433 under date of May 8, 1962. Therefore, our comments with regard to the recommendations listed in the said report are also basically same to what we have stated:
Regarding Recommendation (1) - BES is the handling agency for excess equipment procured abroad and has kept necessary records. On the part of CUSA, matters pertaining to this project are handled by its various offices in accordance with their respec- tive functions. The Second Division of CUSA handles programming and allocation and has records as required; similarly do the other offices. The detailed Arrival Report is now submitted by BES within about two weeks from the date of arrival. Considering the various steps necessary at the port and time required by BES for checking and listing, we think this is reasonable. No reorganization of the operating system is deemed necessary.
Regarding Recommendation (2) - During a period about one year ago, sizable quantities of excess supplies which had not been requested or were in excess of the requested quantities were shipped from USA under PIO/C 00043 and PIO/C 80450, the procure- ment ageney of under both PIO/C's 80450, the procurement agency of under both PIO/C's being GSA/FSS/FUW Efforts had constantly been made to utilize these unexpected arrivals to the best advantage. Major portion has thus been allocated or sold though there is still a portion which remains in BES yard and is being under sale by CTC. The quantities of unsold items have been considerably reduced through months of efforts by relevant offices.
Regarding Recommendation (3) - The storage condition at BES yard has been improved as practicable. As the excess equipment are stored in BES yard only for a short period and consist mainly of heavy construction equipment which can stand weathering, no construction of warehouse for their storage is ever contemplated.
叔 je
la 4/10 / 0 7/10
71
國史馆 Acadeinia Histórica
70

paragraphs.content: 青春七月一日七三取善、肉桂阿例部份 Jos Proj. 39-471 IP

The audit report concerning Excess Equipment Project No. 99-471 appears to be basically same as its draft which had been sent to CUSA for clearance but was not cleared by CUSA on account of its being not consistent with the facts and returned per CUSA letter C2-62-1433 under date of May 8, 1962. Therefore, our comments with regard to the recommendations listed in the said report are also basically same to what we have stated:

Regarding Recommendation (1) - BES is the handling agency for excess equipment procured abroad and has kept necessary records. On the part of CUSA, matters pertaining to this project are handled by its various offices in accordance with their respec- tive functions. The Second Division of CUSA handles programming and allocation and has records as required; similarly do the other offices. The detailed Arrival Report is now submitted by BES within about two weeks from the date of arrival. Considering the various steps necessary at the port and time required by BES for checking and listing, we think this is reasonable. No reorganization of the operating system is deemed necessary.

Regarding Recommendation (2) - During a period about one year ago, sizable quantities of excess supplies which had not been requested or were in excess of the requested quantities were shipped from USA under PIO/C 00043 and PIO/C 80450, the procure- ment ageney of under both PIO/C's 80450, the procurement agency of under both PIO/C's being GSA/FSS/FUW Efforts had constantly been made to utilize these unexpected arrivals to the best advantage. Major portion has thus been allocated or sold though there is still a portion which remains in BES yard and is being under sale by CTC. The quantities of unsold items have been considerably reduced through months of efforts by relevant offices.

Regarding Recommendation (3) - The storage condition at BES yard has been improved as practicable. As the excess equipment are stored in BES yard only for a short period and consist mainly of heavy construction equipment which can stand weathering, no construction of warehouse for their storage is ever contemplated.
